position.marginalia_text: nisi spiritus solos, vel quod natura[m] spiritus vel corporis in se co[n]tineat. Sed hos proiectos super corpora sine illorum mundatione, viderunt non perfectos colores dare, vel ex toto corrumpere denigrare, advere, & defo[e]dare. Notetis ergo, quod dicim[us] sine illorum mundatione. Igitur mundatio debet fidei, &id_est; ista à ingredine, et tenebris: et ita sentit Hermes. sed quid est illud quod parit ista[m] nigredine[m]? certe humiditas aquosa et advstiva. Vnde Author trium verboru[m] [etc.]

marginalia.translation: Unless souls alone, or that the spirit of the body cointains in itself nature. But those cast over the body without purgation of those saw them give to those not perfected colours... You will note htat we say without purgation. Therefore, it must be purged from the blackness and darkness. And thus says Hermes But what actually causes this blackness? Certainly a watery and combusting moistness. THis says the Author of the Book of Three Words.

position.marginalia_text: Fumus albus est anima et spiritus illorum corporum, quor[um] animas iam extraximus, et iteru[m] eas suis corporibus coniunximus. Ista ergo anima suu[m] corpus ingressa, dealbat ip[su]m, et mundat ab omni nigredine. Vnde Parmenides in

marginalia.translation: White smoke is the breath and soul of bodies the breaths of which we have already extracted and we have joint with their bodies. This breath, which is entered into its body, has whitened itself and is cleansed of all its blackness. On this Parmenides [says] in [...].
